Reviews.Title: Very Good computer, but NOT a Workstation....
Reviews.Author: Christian Baude "BoomBoom"
Reviews.Content: + Screen is good, albeit fuzzy and not crisp.+ Auto calibration is an interesting feature.+ Nice solid full size keyboard.+ Nice and fast. but that is an Intel feature.+ Runs cool compared to AMD chips.+ Nice bright screen, but dull for photography.- Photoshop CS works, but unuseable on IPS screen. Adobe is aware and working on a fix.+ Lightroom CS works OK+ Camera is decent for Skype, et al.+ Memory easy to add, but may break the plastic tabs to door.  Be GENTLE!- Annoying fingerprint logo at start up that cannot be personalized.+ Fan intake in the back, not under.  Great for laptop use, or dusty desktops, keeps vents clean.- NO HD activity light  <- MAJOR Feature failure. It's a black box ready for malware and viruses.- No Wifi hard disconnect switch <- 2nd MAJOR failure for hackers- No WiFi indicator light <- ibid.- No visible CapsLock or NumLock light.- Missing power 'on' light on PSU brick.- Screen flexes when you grab one corner and move it- No lid lock, no area for fingers to grab screen, hard to lift w/o bending screen- Touchpad accidentally clicks all over the place when touched with palms.- Missing right/left mouse button, they literally are virtual- Touch pad actually useless, Mouse is mandatory for REAL work.- No enable/disable touchpad (!)- No sleep/hibernate button you have to use Fn-4- Meaningless "projector" button that does the exact same as Win+P (!)- Fn lock is inverted, so a green light has to be illuminated to have standard Fn button operation (!}- Changing drive bay requires removal of memory/HD panel which is flimsy and can break plastic tabs and uses a tiny screw.- Need to carry a screwdriver to change bay, cannot swap external drives.- Proprietary HD basket.- Actually a downgrade in quality from the W530.- CPU throttling issue, not visible to the average user.Lack of indicator lights is a very annoying issue for a $2,300 WORKSTATION. The issue occurs when running large Statistical analysis, Malwarebyte scan, Database conversion or analysis, softeware installs and upgrade/updates and other such real world Workstation tasks.Often I do not know if the computer is working, program crashes, or 'locked' if there is no screen activity.  It's like working with a Black Box.  Indeed, the engineering is aiming at the Apple, but not in the precision rugged physical case.  Cheap plastic, and tabs that break to access the DVD unlock, and memory bay.Also annoying is the lack of "on" light on the PSU brick. I have an in line switch to turn off the power, but I need to 'feel' the switch as a reminder that I turned off the power, else the batteries might get killed, overheat, or with a danger of short/overheating and burning the carpet or building from the brick!!

Reviews.Title: Not a ThinkPad
Reviews.Author: Pat
Reviews.Content: I bought mine direct from Lenovo at a very fair price.My suggestion to someone planning to buy a W540 is to physically touch one first. I would have returned my W540 but I blame myself not Lenovo for my disappointment and I procrastinated beyond my 30 day window. I should have read ALL the reviews and found one to touch. My expectation of the machine was a Core I5 T410 on steroids which it is not. It processes like a T410 on steroids but it is a tin can as compared to a T410. I could have bought another brand for half the price with equal or better processing. All the little icon lights that show wifi, Bluetooth, charging, read/write, etc. are gone; all of them. All the buttons are gone; speaker, microphone, and even the blue Thinkvantage button. The charger could be used for a weapon. Any weight saved by making the computer body cheaper is more than offset by the brick of a charger. The keyboard is nothing like the old Think-pad. The F keys will drive you to drink, they depict the Fn function, which is primary, and the F# is so small you need a magnifying glass to see it. The key board flexes especially if you hit a key too hard and the finish on the keys picks up hand oils making it look and feel greasy. The feel of the keys and their shape is not the legendary ThinkPad series keyboard. The body is not like a T410 as it too feels cheap and there is no cover latch. I really don't see much difference between this and a Core I7 in an E, G or Z series that cost significantly less even after you customize them!!! The touch-pad reacts strangely, thankfully you can turn it off. Everything that made a Lenovo worth the extra money is gone. My old T410 is sitting right next to my new W540 as I type this and I find myself longing for my old friend. The W540 is fast, it was not crapified, it works flawlessly after a month of use but it isn't a Lenovo Think-pad for anyone who has used the Think-pad series as I have since IBM introduced it. I am sure some will like the fact that it is now like all the other machines on the market but I don't. Should you decide to buy one when it arrives go to Program Files\Lenovo\Hotkey\tpnumlk.exe and change the name (.ex) and reboot to stop the big black box with the num lock message from covering half the screen  --  the only complaint with computing function.

Reviews.Title: Great value, great machine.  no problems
Reviews.Author: Tek "~Tek"
Reviews.Content: I have no complaints about this machine.  It was a great discount off Lenovo's website, and it's loaded.  I would like to have seen some better specs listed on the Amazon listing here, but with some research I was able to find most of the spec list from Lenovo and other sources.Ever since Lenovo broke off from IBM, they have been screamin' along in performance and reliability.  I have a W520 as my work-issued machine, and I love it so much that I decided to get another one for my personal machine.  I debated on the W530 because I could use the same docks and accessories, but ultimately decided on the W540 because I wanted the updated screen, backlit keyboard, and other features.  It's got the 256GB SSD, 8GB ram, the IPS screen, color sensor, fingerprint reader, and more.  I really like that Lenovo gives you a choice of Windows 7 or 8, and it actually came with Windows 7 pre-installed!  No stupid windows 8!!!  It's NOT a touchscreen.The W540 is a lot thinner than the W520 and W530.  It feels solid, doesn't flex and twist like so many thin laptops these days, and it has tons of expansion capability.  In addition to the Optical bay, there is actually 2 M.2 slots for expansion.  one is taken by the WiFi card, the other is ready to accept a WWAN card, OR an additional storage drive.  I believe it has the 42mm size slot, tho I have not actually measured it yet.  There is a LOT of confusion on the M.2 standard, and I was not able to find ANYTHING about this pre-purchase... so it was a nice discovery to find that I can install a second storage drive AND keep the optical drive installed too!  Not that I really need an optical drive very often...  everything is download now!Like its predecessors, the W540 has 4 memory slots, for 32GB support.  It takes a standard 2.5" SATA drive, so you can get all manner of SSDs for it.  I think the optical bay is one of the new thin line ones, 9.5mm I think...  versus the old 11.5mm ones.  So if you put in a carriage for a second drive, be sure you check it to make sure you're ordering the right one.  It also comes with a mini-DisplayPort (mDP) (thunderbolt) port, USB 3.0 ports, one USB port that will charge with the laptop off, an analog video out, SD card reader, PCI Express 34 (not 54) slot, and gig-e port.The W series is designed to be a "Workstation"... it supports everything you want in a true desktop replacement.  I will be replacing my desktop with it soon.Nice job Lenovo... keep it up!!!The accessories, power cord, dock, and other such are completely new for the W540... so get ready to shell out some cash if you need extras.  I will be picking up a dock soon.

Reviews.Title: So far so good
Reviews.Author: casio20124
Reviews.Content: Everything is excellent except the screen sometimes flickers, especially during vedio displaying. I don't know why. Because of its dual graphics or configurations of the player?

Reviews.Title: I'm in shock that anything this bad could be produced by a major brand like Lenovo
Reviews.Author: Eric Carlson
Reviews.Content: I was given this machine at work as my primary system. I'm reviewing this completely on one feature, the trackpad. I'm in shock that anything this bad could be produced by a major brand like Lenovo. This is a button-less trackpad, a knock-off of Apple I suppose, but it is so poorly executed that it is virtually unusable. The response is heavy and literally makes a "clunk" when pressed. I did turn off the tap-to-click feature which provided a slight improvement in usability but still, any time you need to do a lot of repetitive clicking between the right and left button "areas" it is an exercise in pure frustration. Not only is it frustrating but my thumb actually gets sore because the response is so heavy. The only thing that makes this machine usable for me is that I put it on a stand and use a wireless keyboard and mouse. Aside from that, there is nothing else outstanding about it that would make me want to go out and buy it for a personal machine. I should say that I am a programmer and use this side by side with a MacBook Pro so perhaps I'm spoiled by the MacBook but the difference in feel and usability between the two is night and day.

Reviews.Title: Like it a lot, a little getting used to...
Reviews.Author: Faye Carraway "Jesse Miga"
Reviews.Content: This was pretty much the only machine that had all the specs I wanted - screen is great, I put an extra SSD in the ultraslim bay for storage which works as expected. Keyboard is better than others and not hard to get used to compared to my old w520. Trackpad takes some getting used to but is easy if you learn to use it without your thumb. I was aghast when I first tried it but quickly realized the way it is apparently built to be used. Wireless AC is slower than expected but hoping to upgrade it at some point.Build quality is solid, definitely more simple than previous versions. I prefer the feel of the w520 but this one will be fine.

ProductInfo.Features:
Processor: i7-4800MQ, 8GBx1 ram (32GB Max), 256 Solid State Drive, 3K (2880x1620)display, NVIDIA K2100M graphics, HD720p camera
X-Rite Color Calibration, Backlit Keyboard, Fingerprint Reader, Bluetooth 4.0, Optical: DVD+-RW, 7260 wireless ac
Ports: Two USB 3.0, two USB 2.0 (one Always On), VGA, Mini DisplayPort / Thunderbolt ethernet (RJ-45), Dock connector
Windows 7 Professional 64 preinstalledthrough downgrade rights in Windows 8 Pro 64-bit
3 Year Lenovo Depot Warranty
